This report was prepared by Ying Qian, Principal Financial Economist, Governance, Finance and

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Uzbekistan requested the assistance of the ADB to rationalize and 
strengthen the policy, legal and regulatory framework for the corporate sector and restructure 
state-owned enterprises (SOEs) and enterprises with state ownership. A Fact-Finding Mission 
visited  Tashkent  during  4- 12  November  2002  and  reached  an  understanding  with  the 
Government on the objectives, scope, cost, financing, and implementation arrangements for the 
technical assistance (TA).1 The TA logical framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Macroeconomic Environment. Uzbekistan performed better economically than most 
former Soviet Union republics in the mid-1990s due to favorable prices for its major export 
commodities such as cotton and gold. However, slow progress in economic liberalization and 
various negative external shocks such as declining cotton and gold prices and the Russian 
financial crisis in 1998 have generated difficulties for the Uzbek economy. The Government 
agreed to undergo an  International Monetary Fund (IMF) staff-monitored program (SMP) in 
December 2001, which envisaged implementing some key economic reform policies, including 
reforming the agricultural sector, enhancing market competition, and narrowing the gap between 
the  over-the-counter  (OTC)  exchange  rate  and  the  parallel  market  rate.  Progress  in 
implementing the SMP has been mixed. While the gap between the exchange rates was 
brought down from 110% at the beginning of 2002 to less than 30% in early November 2002, 
through ad hoc monetary interventions, the formal and informal controls on foreign exchange 
access have prevented further closing the gap to 20%, a June 2002 target agreed upon by IMF 
and the Government.  
 
3.  The fast depreciation of the exchange rate over the past year has had a significant 
impact on consumer prices, the profitability and debt servicing of certain enterprises, and on the 
banking system. The share of external debt to gross domestic product (GDP) rose to 41% at the 
official exchange rate in 2001. It is likely that the debt ratios will further rise sharply. The impact 
on the budget is also serious as the debt service cost of Government borrowing will increase 
and Government guarantees issued for SOE borrowings will likely be called. IMF estimates the 
budget deficit to increase from 2.5% of GDP in 2001 to about 3.5% in 2002 with the financing 
gap close to 0.5% of GDP, or about $70 million. 
 
4.  The  Enterprise  Sector.  Uzbekistan’s  corporate  sector  which  comprises  110,000 
registered enterprises of various types and sizes is a major claimant of financial and human 
resources.  About  52,000  SOEs  have  gone  through  the  first  round  of  corporatization  and 
privatization through the stock exchange, auctions or tenders. Most have been corporatized 
either as joint-stock companies (JSCs)2 or limited-liability companies. At present, the State holds 
shares in over 3,600 enterprises, including 168 strategic enterprises in which it holds more than 
25% of the shares. The industry sector value-added is relatively small at 14% of GDP by the 
end of 2001. There are 26 large production and trade associations (PTAs) that control 1,608 
member enterprises and  29 national holding companies (NHCs) that formed as JSCs. Five 
major strategic enterprises with state ownership are not formed as JSCs. In the year 2000, 43% 
of the unprofitable enterprises had state shareholdings and accounted for 86.3% of the total 
losses of the enterprise sector. In 2001, the situation worsened when the same ratios climbed to 
71.4% and 94.7%, respectively. The labor productivity of private enterprises is about 2-3 times

higher and incidence of insolvency lower than that in state-owned and partially state-owned

5.  Bankruptcy and Enterprise Restructuring. Bankruptcies have risen in recent years 
due to unfavorable economic conditions and the sharp depreciation of the official exchange 
rate.3 However, reorganization after bankruptcy has not always been successful in enhancing 
the viability of the enterprise sector. Moreover, progress in restructuring has been slow because 
of several weaknesses in the legal and regulatory framework and concerns over the likely social 
impact. The Government has adopted a program of modifying, restructuring, and liquidating of 
over 400 medium and large enterprises and established the State Committee for Economic 
Insolvency of Enterprises (CEIE) to provide leadership in policy and regulatory oversight. CEIE 
is currently analyzing enterprise data and preparing plans for restructuring of enterprises. It has 
submitted a draft bill amending the Bankruptcy Law. The Government is considering a proposal 
to  separate  nonperforming  loans  (NPLs)  from  commercial  banks  and  establish  an  asset-
restructuring agency to arrange for NPLs restructuring or liquidating. 
 
6.  Privatization.  The  State  Property  Committee  (GKI)  is  responsible  for  facilitating 
privatization and managing the assets and shares of strategic and large SOEs and JSCs. GKI 
implements a privatization program that the Parliament periodically reviews and approves. The 
privatization program for 2003-2005 targets an additional 4,000 SOEs and JSCs. Special 
programs  have  been  drawn  up  for  the  sale  of  telecommunications,  energy,  and  financial 
enterprises. Despite recent progress,4 privatization is still slow and incoherent because of (i) 
investors' concerns over current account convertibility, (ii) Government's unwillingness to cede 
majority  ownership  to  foreign  investors,  (iii)  continued  State  interference  with  investment 
decisions, (iv) insufficient capacity for evaluating and structuring privatization transactions, (v) 
weak capital markets, and (vi) legal and regulatory impediments to investments. As a result, 
strategic investors, both domestic and foreign, are reluctant to commit to long-term equity 
investment in Uzbekistan. 
 
7.  Corporate Governance. In addition to adverse economic conditions, enterprises in 
Uzbekistan suffer from poor corporate governance due to (i) "upstream" issues related to weak 
and sometimes adverse external policy and legal environment for corporate governance, (ii) 
“downstream” issues related to inadequate corporate legal structure and enterprises’ inability to 
comply with legal norms, and (iii) underdeveloped supporting infrastructure such as financial 
management system and capital markets for better corporate governance. 
 
8.  Currently, existing barriers to entry and exit of enterprises in key economic sectors are 
considerable  due  to  the  inadequate  legal  and  operational  framework  for  insolvency,  and 
restrictions on market competition. While the Government has committed to IMF to reform the 
foreign exchange regime, it has not addressed the issue of SOE subsidies, which operate 
through dual exchange rates and credit guarantees. Despite attempts to streamline the tax 
system, the tax burden on enterprises is still high and the system of tax administration causes 
undue difficulties for enterprises. No credible, independent mechanism for third-party resolution 
of disputes between enterprises exists and the legal framework for pledges needs improvement. 
The Central Bank of Uzbekistan expects that a decree on nonjudicial foreclosure of collateral 
will be made effective once amendments to Civil Code are adopted.

exchange rate of SUM100-200/dollar a few years ago. The current official exchange rate is SUM800-900/dollar.

9.  A critical downstream issue is the inadequacy of information and protection for minority 
shareholders.  For  instance,  the  Government  enjoys  disproportionate  rights  and  frequently 
issues new shares based on arbitrary revaluations. As a result the share capital of the minority 
shareholders is diluted. The supervisory councils in many JSCs lack independence and clearly 
defined fiduciary roles. The state trustees and trustee managers enjoy undue and preferential 
powers. PTAs and NHCs de facto play the role of the line ministries and are involved in policy 
making and regulatory functions as well as operational oversight. The convoluted ownership 
and cross-shareholding structures among many JSCs and PTAs5 result in inefficiencies through 
cross-subsidization and financial leveraging.  
 
10.  As  for  the  environment  for  corporate  governance,  the  Government's  prescribed 
accounting and auditing norms have yet to meet international standards. Currently, the capital 
markets  regulator  is  a  division  of  GKI  and  therefore  lacks  both  legal  and  functional 
independence. The Securities Law is not well-integrated with other legislation on companies, 
and  the  institutional  capability  and  enforcement  authority  under  the  existing  regulatory 
framework are weak. The stock exchange does not have self-regulatory capability and capital 
markets  participants  such  as  securities  firms,  brokers,  and  institutional  investors  lack 
institutional  capacity.  Lastly,  there  are  no  significant  institutional  investors  on  the  capital 
markets. The privatization investment funds (PIFs) created in 1996 are widely perceived to be 
ineffective and they own only about 0.15% of shares issued by JSCs. 
 
11.  Legal and Regulatory Framework. The legal and regulatory framework on enterprises 
includes  laws  on  JSCs  and  shareholder  protection,  banks  and  banking activity, securities 
market and the stock exchange, competition and antimonopoly, and bankruptcy. These laws are 
implemented under the main umbrella of the Civil Code. In addition, the Cabinet of Ministers 
(COM) and the President have issued a large  number of resolutions and decrees to give 
specific  directives  or  additional  powers  not  granted  in  the  legislation.  Considerable 
inconsistencies  appear  within  and  across  laws,  resolutions,  and  decrees.  The  Supreme 
Economic  Court  is  understaffed  and  lacks  adequate  institutional  capability  and  coherent 
procedures to enforce economic laws. The capacity to enforce court decisions is inadequate. 
 
12.  Social Protection. Uzbekistan faces a serious challenge in providing social protection 
as part of the economic restructuring process. Although the registered unemployment rate is 
less than 1% in recent years, the actual, unregistered unemployment rate, or underemployment 
rate,  is  estimated  to  be  4-6%.  Restructuring  the  agriculture  enterprises  since  1998  has 
retrenched more than 400,000 farm employees in rural areas. The Ministry of Labor estimates 
that every year, an additional 60,000 persons will lose their jobs due to bankruptcy and 55,000 
due to restructuring in urban areas in the coming years, and the number of people receiving 
unemployment assistance will double. The pension system is a pay-as-you-go scheme and 
there is no plan yet to convert it into a funded scheme. The magnitude of outstanding social 
security liabilities stemming from enterprise restructuring, which can pose significant risks to the 
Government’s financial position is still not clear. 
 
13.  Operations and Strategy of the ADB and Other Sources. ADB has provided TA 
support to review the institutional and internal control structures within PTAs, and  enhance 
awareness of corporate governance.6 The TA has recommended that the Government gradually 
dismantle  the  PTA  structures.  The  Government  has  requested  further  ADB  assistance  to 
facilitate initiatives for restructuring and liquidating the targeted enterprises that are operationally

enterprises.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
14.  The TA will facilitate Uzbekistan’s economic transition of the enterprise sector. The TA 
will  (i)  support  the  formulation  of  a  strategy  for  corporate  governance  and  restructuring 
enterprises; (ii) launch restructuring initiatives in the state enterprise sector; (iii) rationalize and 
strengthen the enabling policy, legal, and regulatory framework within which the corporate 
sector operates, and (iv) enhance the capacity for regulatory oversight of enterprises in a 
market-based environment. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA has two components. Component A for sector policy and enterprise restructuring 
will cover three areas: 
 
(i)  Industrial policy and regulatory assessment. Evaluate fiscal vulnerability due 
to operational and financial weaknesses in enterprises; assess the adequacy of 
industry  sector  policies;  evaluate  the  tax  regime;  assess  the  role  of  capital 
markets; recommend regulatory and institutional reforms; assist in developing 
effective mechanisms for involving commercial banks in financial restructuring of 
enterprises; and develop institutional mechanisms to enhance capacity in all 
these areas.  
 
(ii)  Enterprise  restructuring  and  development  of  a  social  safety  net 
mechanism. Select a sample of nonviable  enterprises with State shares and 
help  initiate  their  closure,  liquidation,  and  restructuring;  review and identify 
constraints  on  debt  restructuring  and  transfer  of  ownership;  estimate  the 
restructuring  costs;  evaluate  the  impact  of  enterprise  restructuring  on  the 
workforce, develop detailed labor restructuring options, and design adjustment 
programs to mitigate any adverse effects; and start formulating strategies leading 
for establishing a multi-pillar pension system. 
 
(iii)  Legal  and  judicial  assessment  to  support  enterprise  restructuring  and 
private sector development. Strengthen the legal and judicial framework to 
support  enterprise  restructuring,  execution  of  pledges,  and  resolution  of 
commercial disputes; simplify the legal and regulatory framework to facilitate 
postprivatization  and  private  sector  development;  identify  impediments  in 
enforcing commercial legislation and judicial decisions; and design mechanisms 
to strengthen the role of legal and judicial institutions in this regard. 
 
16.  Component B will evaluate the need for establishing an enterprise restructuring equity 
fund that could take up strategic long-term equity investments to effectively reduce Government 
ownership and attract private investments.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.45 million equivalent, including foreign 
exchange cost of $835,000 and local currency cost of $615,000 equivalent. ADB will finance the 
foreign exchange cost of $835,000 and the local currency cost of $165,000 equivalent on a 
grant basis, from its TA funding program. The Government will contribute $450,000 in kind for 
office space, counterpart staff, transportation, and other services. Appendix 2 presents detailed 
cost estimates. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  CEIE will be the Executing Agency (EA) for both components. An interagency working 
group will be established, under the leadership of the chairperson of CEIE, comprising members 
from GKI, Ministry of Labor, Ministry of Justice, Center on Control and Coordination of the 
Securities Market, Central Bank of Uzbekistan, and the Supreme Economic Court. The working 
group  will  coordinate  the  TA  and  give  effective  counterpart  support  for  the  respective 
components.  CEIE  will  provide  office  space,  counterpart  staff,  transportation,  and  logistic 
support to the consultants.  
 
19.  The TA will engage 10 international consultants for a total of 30 person-months. The 
consultants (28 person-months) for Component A will be an  industry policy and regulatory 
specialist (6) as the team leader, three enterprise restructuring and privatization specialists (4 
each), a social safety net specialist (2), a taxation specialist (2), a capital markets specialist (2), 
and two  legal experts (2 each). Component B will engage a private equity investment fund 
specialist (2). Ten domestic consultants will provide 30 person-months of inputs in the same 
areas. The terms of reference and reporting arrangements are in Appendix 3. Component A will 
be tendered to an international firm based on a simplified technical proposal, using the quality- 
and cost-based selection method. Consultants for component B will be recruited individually. All 
the consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  for  selecting  and  engaging  domestic 
consultants. The TA will begin in February 2003 and will be completed in December 2003. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for Enterprise Restructuring and Corporate Governance, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants (30 person-months) 
1.  All international consultants will have significant academic qualifications and expertise in 
their relevant areas, preferably in Central Asian republics or similar environments. While the 
team leader will coordinate the tasks, all international consultants will be responsible for certain 
common tasks: (i) formulate the terms of reference for, and oversee the work of their respective 
domestic consultants, (ii) give advice to other experts, and (iii) contribute in formulating an 
overall strategy on enterprise restructuring and corporate governance reforms. 
 
2.  The team leader for component A and the individual consultant for component B will 
submit (i) inception reports 2 weeks after beginning of their services; (ii) interim progress reports 
at appropriate stages of TA implementation; (iii) draft final reports before the conclusion of the 
contract; and (iv) final reports 2 weeks after incorporating the comments of the Executing 
Agency (EA) and the ADB. Training session and workshops will be organized during the 
implementation  period.  The  EA  and  the  team  leader  for  component  A  will  ensure  close 
coordination of the components during that period. 
 
1.  Team Leader/Industry Policy and Regulatory Specialist (6 person-months) 
 
3.  The  consultant  will  be  responsible  for  the  overall  implementation  of  the  technical 
assistance and the timely delivery of quality interim and final reports. He/she should identify the 
macroeconomic impact of foreign exchange-denominated liabilities on selected insolvent state- 
owned enterprises (SOEs) and enterprises with State shares, prepare a profile of major sectors 
in which the SOEs operate, and give policy recommendations on the requirements of sector 
restructuring  designed  to  promote  competition  and  provide  for  market-based  prices.  The 
consultant will focus on policy, institutional, as well as regulatory issues: 
 
(i)  Quantify the magnitude of soft-budget constraints and outstanding receivables 
owed by SOEs to the State budget, commercial banks, the National Pension and 
other  enterprises;  and  assess  the  impact  of  the  financial  and  operational 
restructured SOEs on the budget, banking system, and the pension system. 
(ii)  Develop  various  foreign  exchange  rate  scenarios  and  assess  the impact of 
changes  in  the  exchange  rate  on  the  magnitude  of  foreign  exchange- 
denominated liabilities for SOEs, including the consequential impact on the State 
budget, commercial banks, the National Pension, and other enterprises. 
(iii)  Evaluate the major sectors within which the SOEs operate and assess the extent 
to which prices are market based; where this is not the case, identify critical 
impediments constraining prices, such as trade restrictions, licenses, and price 
controls. 
(iv)  Develop  a  restructuring  strategy  for  the  major  sectors  that  will  promote 
competition and identify mechanisms for addressing social concerns such as 
public sector obligation payments.  
(v)  Prepare  and  implement  training  programs  on  formulating  a  strategy  for 
evaluating  and  restructuring  enterprises,  and  offer  these  programs  to 
Government officials and local professionals involved in enterprise restructuring. 
(vi)  Identify regulatory and institutional reforms that need to be introduced to support 
the proposed changes; estimate the associated economic benefits of regulatory 
reforms and financial costs of institutional reforms and public sector obligations. 
(vii)  Evaluate the operation of the Corporate Governance Center situated at the State 
Property Committee (GKI) and institute sustainable supporting mechanisms and 
capacity building programs for strengthening corporate governance.

(viii)  Based on (i) – (vii), and with inputs from international and domestic consultants, 
coordinate the formulation of a sound strategy for enterprise sector focusing on 
(a) corporate governance reforms, and (b) enterprise restructuring. 
 
2.  Enterprise Restructuring and Privatization Specialists (3 persons, 4 person-
months each) 
 
4.  The consultants should review the industry restructuring plan and list of SOEs that can 
potentially be restructured and prepare due diligence reports for those enterprises. The specific 
terms of reference for each expert will be determined by nature of the enterprise assigned to the 
expert. In particular, the consultants will address the following issues: 
 
(i)  Evaluate controls on foreign investment in Uzbekistan, the law on public offerings 
and private placement, and stock exchange requirements relative to  a public 
offering (listing requirements, restrictions on foreign participation, etc.). 
(ii)  Identify the main issues associated with alternative methods of privatization 
including trade sale, initial public offering, management contract, management 
buyout, and employee share ownership plans. 
(iii)  Select a sample of nonviable SOEs to help initiate their closure and liquidation, 
and select a sample of viable SOEs to help prepare them for restructuring. 
(iv)  Evaluate the corporate structure and the composition of the board of directors of 
selected enterprises to determine suitability for commercial operation. 
(v)  Review  contractual  relationships  of  enterprises  being  restructured  with  third 
parties and assess the implications for restructuring and privatization. 
(vi)  For each selected enterprise, conduct a market analysis to determine the primary 
political, economic, social, technical drivers of cash flows, taking into account 
potential  sector  reforms  in  prices  and  competition.  Review  the  current  loan 
agreements and debt service requirements and compare with expected cash 
flows  after  identifying  constraints  on  any  debt  restructuring  and  transfer  of 
ownership. 
(vii)  Conduct an operational review that encompasses core and noncore operational 
areas and assess the scope for contracting out entities. 
(viii)  Evaluate existing forward plans of the SOEs with regard to both profits and cash 
flow. Identify capital expenditure requirements; understand key assumptions, 
sensitivities, and vulnerabilities. 
(ix)  Consider different options for the equity structure for the enterprises, with varying 
levels of State and foreign ownership and with incentives and protection for small 
local investors. 
(x)  Develop a financial model that gives an indicative value of the enterprises on a 
discounted cash flow basis under various restructuring scenarios. 
(xi)  Assess the extent to which the enterprises are operating above the industry

(xii)  Identify the optimal level of staffing for the different operations of the companies

(xiii)  Evaluate  various  restructuring  options  including  status  quo,  liquidation,

3.  Legal Experts (2 person-months each) 
 
5.  The two legal experts are expected to have significant commercial law background with 
significant exposure to the working of the judiciary in resolving commercial disputes. They will 
give overall legal advice and background to the team of consultants as well as the Government 
on a range of issues relating to enterprise restructuring. In addition to other tasks relevant in the 
legal and judicial areas, the experts will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Review  the  constitutional  and  other  legislative  framework  for  enterprise 
restructuring and privatization to determine whether amendments are necessary 
to  expedite  enterprise  restructuring  and  reorganization,  and  identify  the 
implications of the amendments suggested. 
(ii)  Evaluate the application of the legal framework to the corporate structures and 
the composition of the Board of Directors in the enterprises being restructured. 
(iii)  Examine the legal issues associated with alternative methods of privatization 
including trade sale, initial public offering, management contract, management 
buyout, and plans for employee share of ownership. 
(iv)  Conduct a complete review of the legal framework on pledges, including the 
system for registering and executing pledges. 
(v)  Evaluate the adequacy of the legal and regulatory environment for the operation 
of institutional investors, including the trust law, investment fund law, and law or 
regulation on companies managing investment funds. 
(vi)  Undertake an in-depth review of the commercial dispute resolution process (with 
and without court involvement), and design sound alternative frameworks. 
(vii)  Recommend measures to enhance legal and judicial capacity in the following 
areas:  (a)  all  forms  of  enterprise  restructuring,  (b)  pledge  formulation  and 
execution, (c) effective enforcement of legislation and judicial decisions,  
(viii)  Evaluate other domestic legal issues such as the labor and taxation laws that 
may  impact  on  successful  implementation  of  the  recommended  enterprise 
restructuring and privatization routes. 
 
4.  Social Safety Net Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
6.  The specialist will review the social safety net mechanisms of the Government. The 
specialist will then work with the enterprise restructuring specialists and prepare reports for 
SOEs that may benefit from labor restructuring. The specialist will focus on labor as well as 
pension-system issues: 
 
(i)  Conduct  high-level  labor  assessments  of  enterprises  identified  as  possible 
candidates for enterprise reform, identify the magnitude of pension liabilities and 
assess the extent to which the enterprise can self-fund these liabilities.  
(ii)  Evaluate various labor adjustment options for each enterprise including status 
quo, early retirement, retraining, and redeployment; assess the likely financial 
impact of each option on enterprise profitability and cash flow and likely costs to 
the National Pension; estimate pension expenditure in government budgets and 
identify payroll taxes required to finance the pension systems, and estimate 
potential deficits/surplus situation for next 10-15 years. 
(iii)  Initiate a work plan for establishing the multipillar pension system where the 
public sector concentrates on providing a basic minimum pension -the first pillar, 
while the private sector manages a fully funded scheme.

  5.  Taxation Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
7.  The consultant should review the taxation regime and performance of tax administration 
at central and local levels that affect the financial and operational well-being of enterprises and 
give recommendations for a reform plan. The consultant will undertake these tasks: 
 
(i)  Identify near-to medium-term fiscal objectives of the Government. 
(ii)  With advice from the legal experts, review legal and regulatory framework related 
to  tariff  and  taxation;  identify  any  inconsistencies  and  potential  distortionary 
effects of differential taxes, such as sales and excise tax, value-added tax (VAT), 
etc., on domestic and foreign enterprises and give proposals to eliminate such 
distortions.  
(iii)  Identify opportunities for tax evasion and recommend an incentive compatible 
strategy to reduce such opportunity. 
(iv)  Evaluate the efficiency and effectiveness of the tax operation and administration 
system, specifically in regard to VAT collection and rebates, and identify policy, 
institutional, and legal constraints, as well as responsibility and accountability of 
tax officials; and recommend a near-to medium-term reform plan of the tax policy 
and administration system that is conducive to the growth of the enterprise 
sector. 
 
6.  Capital Markets Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
8.  The consultant should assess the state of development of the securities market in 
Uzbekistan, evaluate its role in facilitating enterprise restructuring and strengthening corporate 
governance, and recommend measures to expedite the development of the institutional investor 
base. The consultant will also assist the Government to introduce fundamental reforms of the 
securities market. In particular, the consultants will undertake these specific tasks: 
 
(i)  Assess the roles of a regulatory and supervisory body for the securities market 
and  recommend  a  plan  for  establishing  an  independent  securities  market 
regulator. 
(ii)  Review applicable securities market regulations and relevant laws and regulation 
that  have  implications  for  the  enforcement  powers  of  the  regulator  and 
recommend  measures  aimed  at  enhancing  the  enforcement  powers  of  the 
securities market regulator and its capacity and skills levels. 
(iii)  Evaluate the education, career background, and skill level of staff working for the 
securities  market  regulator;  obtain  information  on  securities  firms  and  the 
brokerage  industry,  and  institutional  investors;  examine  the  regulations  and 
procedures for self-regulation activities of the stock exchanges; design training 
programs aimed at strengthening the capacity of the stock exchange as a self-
regulatory organization to promote stability and confidence. 
(iv)  Identify  opportunities  to  consolidate  various  laws,  resolutions  and  decrees 
controlling the activities of the securities market into one umbrella Securities Law. 
(v)  Evaluate the technology infrastructure of the securities markets, identify potential 
operational risks, and recommend mitigation measures. 
(vi)  Obtain  from  managing  companies  of  privatization  investment  funds  (PIFs) 
information on size of funds in management, number of investee companies

7.  Private Equity Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
9.  The private sector equity specialist will evaluate the need for and review the legislative 
and regulatory framework, and give policy advice and recommendations for establishing a 
private equity fund for enterprise restructuring. The specific tasks follow: 
 
(i)  Identify as part of the enterprise restructuring process, the economic potential 
and investment opportunities for enterprise restructuring and private equity fund, 
as well as initial pipeline of projects, particularly in areas of bankruptcy, buyouts, 
and restructuring of enterprises. 
(ii)  Evaluate the competitive landscape for enterprise restructuring and private equity 
in  central  Asia  and  Uzbekistan,  and  identify  sources  of  direct  and  indirect 
competitions. 
(iii)  Based on the formulated strategy and progress on enterprise restructuring in 
component  A,  identify  the  pipeline  of  investment  projects;  formulate  capital- 
raising  strategies  for  attracting  international,  government,  and  private 
participation especially potential anchor investors.  
(iv)  Recommend means to establish an operational framework for the fund including 
an investment strategy and criteria for assuring the quality of investment projects 
and risk management; survey the experiences of similar funds in similar markets 
for formulating an exit strategy. 
(v)  With advice from the legal expert in component A, review the legislative and 
regulatory framework and recommend reform and improvement measures to 
facilitate enterprise restructuring and operation of private equity funds in general.
